participants.participant: Hans Dieter Pötsch, Finance and Controlling
Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Group Sales and Marketing

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen welcome to Volkswagen Conference Call for the First Three Months of 2008. I am joined today by Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Volkswagen AG responsible for Finance and Controlling; and by Detlef Wittig, Executive Vice President, Volkswagen AG responsible for Group Sales and Marketing.
As usual, you can also follow the webcast and download the chart from our website volkswagenag.com/IR-webcasting. Questions can be sent by email or called in.
Before we start, I would like to mention that after the speech of Mr. Pötsch and Mr. Wittig, we will first respond to the questions of analysts and later answer those of journalists.
I would now like to ask Mr. Pötsch to give a few comments on the highlight of the first quarter of 2008 before Mr. Wittig goes into detail of the deliveries to customer. Mr. Pötsch, please.

Thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen, also a warm welcome from my side to this conference call. I am very pleased to be here today to discuss our good performance against a backdrop of falling growth in the developed economies and an almost daily barrage of newspaper headlines.

I am pleased to say that our strategy in the emerging markets of China and Brazil and our early entry to Eastern Europe via Škoda have provided us a useful counterbalance to this declining growth. Consequently, I am pleased to report that despite the impacts of Easter falling in the first quarter we were able to grow deliveries to customers by 7% representing a growth rate of four times the global market. And we will of course not stop here. Already this year we have presented the Passat CC and the stunning Scirocco, the return of a classic.

The all new Audi Q5 with the unique sleek silhouette was shown in Beijing, which followed shortly on from the A3 Cabriolet and the A4 Avant. Škoda has launched a new Superb, and Seat is a few weeks away from the start of production of the sporty all new Ibiza to name just a few highlights. Our brands design language is becoming clearer, our portfolio of cars more complete and customers are buying our vehicles as never before.

When we turn to the operating profit performance, all brands as well as financial services, were able to improve their earnings thanks to our continuous focus on strong cost control and capital discipline, which is reflected in this performance. Our operating profits increased significantly by 20.9% to €1.3 billion. Consolidated pre-tax profit also increased strongly by 27.8%, to €1.4 billion, 0.3 billion above the comparable 2007 figure.

Ladies and gentlemen, we announced in March the agreement to increase our stake in Scania and I'm pleased to confirm that the transaction is proceeding according to plan with an expected completion in summer 2008. We will fully consolidate Scania within our financial reporting from this point.

The cash outflow for the share purchase will also occur at this time. I'll give you a few more details on our financial performance later. Let me now hand over to Mr. Wittig who will give you an overview of our positive sales development. Mr. Wittig, your turn please.

Thank you. Welcome also from my side ladies and gentlemen. As a very first and general remark, I think I can probably say we had a good start, a good sales start into this new year 2008 and as you can see on the chart, the first column on the chart, on the left side shows our total Volkswagen Group sales performance for the first three months. We were able to increase our sales as mentioned already by Mr. Pötsch by 7% up to 1,572,000 cars and we can say this is a new sales record for the Group. At the same time and during the same period of the first three months, the total car market, world car market increased only by 2% so this means that we were gaining market share.

Now looking at the individual brands of the Group from left to right, to the right from Volkswagen Passenger Cars down to Commercial Vehicles, first of all, the Volkswagen Passenger Cars increased sales to customers by an overall of 8.3% up to 920,000 units and that also was a sales record for the brand Volkswagen and that sales record was made – was driven by some countries in Europe but especially by our emerging markets. In Europe, we were able to increase our sales in Germany by 8.6%, yes, we take into consideration that there was a lower base in the first quarter of last year but also at the same time we were able to increase our sales in Poland by 44% and now the new emerging markets for us Russia plus 48% and in Brazil plus 22% and of course in China again a plus of 25%. So those countries were driving the Volkswagen Passenger Cars sales.

Turning to Audi, Audi sales were up by 1.3% that refers to a total volume of 250,000 cars. It is also the best first quarter in Audi's history and it was mainly driven by the Audi A3 and the new A5 Coupé and the Coupé very successful for a Coupé version with over 13,000 deliveries in the first quarter.

Going to Škoda, Škoda continued its very positive trend with a further strong plus of 15.7% up to 173,000 units and that includes for the first time a measurable number of 16,000 Octavias built and sold in China; also a sales record as mentioned before.

Turning to Seat, Seat however we suffered a decline of minus 7.5% but with the strong base in the Spanish market and the Spanish market showing a weak performance in total, the Spanish market is down by 15% in the first quarter of this year. And still the new Ibiza just being around the corner we think it was still a good performance and we have no concern, we're not worried about the first quarter results of Seat.

Bentley also was down by 17.8% and that again refers to the first quarter of last year, where we saw the high demand last year of the launch of the Bentley GTC version. We expect a more balanced demand in 2008 with a full year target on the same level as in 2007.

Last but not least our Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles, they had an excellent quarter with deliveries to customers increasing by plus 12% up to 123,000 units. All model lines contributed to this success and our commercial vehicles were mainly concentrating and successful in the Western European market say in France, Britain, and Italy.

Now turning to our sales by market areas and this chart, we will go through it in detail but I would like to focus the first remark on the two columns to your right, which shows our performance in South America with a plus of 11% and in Asia-Pacific with a plus of 28%. So those areas were very positive in driving our sales.

Now again starting from left to right, Europe. Europe, a mixed performance because we will have to look into Western Europe on one hand and then into Central and Eastern Europe on the other hand. In Western Europe, our sales declined slightly by 0.7% year-on-year and that was mainly due to the weak markets in Italy and Spain, which combined, showed a fall of 14,000 units.

Balancing this, that was our delivery performance in Germany, France, and the U.K. where we were up by almost 12,000 units. On the other hand, in a rather stable German market and slightly recovering as compared with the first quarter of last year, we were able to reach a record market share of 32%.

As far as Central and Eastern Europe is concerned, we saw a very successful start in the year with an increase of our sales by 18%. And that was significantly supported by our sales in Russia. Sales went up by plus 57% and also a recovery in Poland and the Polish market at the same time with a plus of 16%.

Now turning to North America, North America delivery shows, they show here a decrease of minus 5.7% but we will have to sort of differentiate between the U.S. and Mexico. In the U.S., I think we were quite successful at turning around the Volkswagen brand sales. The Volkswagen brand showed an increase of nearly 13% and we are quite confident that we have reached a turnaround situation for Volkswagen in the United States.

Mexico, however, and that is part of the North American sales volume here, Mexico saw a decline of 15% and that has contributed to a decline of the total market, and at the same time a weaker performance of the SEAT brand in Mexico.

Next column shows South America and South Africa, as mentioned before, a very positive trend. But to point, at South America only excluding south of Africa, we had a plus of 18% driven by Brazil with a plus of 23%. So we are doing quite well in South America. However, on the other side, in South Africa we saw a decline of 30% and that is mainly due to a very weak total market, the market went down there by minus 20%.

The last column shows Asia Pacific, in total a plus of 28%, but that was mainly driven by our performance in China. Our sales there grew by plus 32% and this is the continuation of the positive trend of last year and even an acceleration, because last year we had a growth rate of 28% and now 32%. Also included in the Asia Pacific sales volume is India, where we saw a growth of 46% mainly due to the Škoda sales in India.

Turning to the individual brands, if you highlight on some of the models of the Volkswagen brand, the Passat CC and the Scirocco shown here on the picture had an excellent reaction from journalists and dealers since their first showing. The Passat CC in Detroit and at the Geneva Motor Show and the Scirocco over the world premier at the Geneva Motor Show.

However, when we look at those models driving the sales success in the first three months, we saw a very positive effect resulting from a success of our Golf sales in South America with an increase rate of 20% there. And the newly introduced Chinese models, Sagitar and Magotan, very successful in the Chinese market.

In Europe, however we saw a very successful new Golf Variant with some 26,000 deliveries, a positive performance in the first quarter. And certainly – and I would still like to mention this, the success of our Tiguan with actually over 100,000 orders taken to-date. And we are working hard on cutting down the waiting list by extra shifts that we have put in place in order to satisfy our customers' demand as quickly as possible.

Now turning to Audi; with 251,000 cars delivered in the first quarter, Audi reported the best first quarter in its history. This success is the result of the enlargement certainly of the modern range of the model offer. And certainly with the new Audi A4 Sedan, that we introduced end of last year, we saw a very strong performance, a plus of 16%. And the Audi A4 Avant, which is shown here on the picture, we have just launched this car a week ago and we can probably say that we have been able to take 36,000 orders already for this new car. And driven also – this Audi success was also driven as I mentioned before by A5 coupé.

Turning to Škoda; Škoda continued their success during January to March this year and also had a new sales record with 173,000 cars sold, increase rate of 15.7%, the highest increase rate of our group brands. And as I mentioned it earlier, in China we started this year the production of the Octavia and this will certainly give us an additional push in the second half of 2000 – well in the second half of this year because we will then introduce also in October this year the Fabia in the Chinese market.

The basis for the worldwide success is the Octavia line with the Octavia Sedan and Combi version. And as shown for the first time last year, the Roomster is also well accepted by our customers and now the new Fabia Hatchback contributed also some 9,000 cars to the total gain of 23,000 cars this year.

The new Superb that is shown here in this chart will be introduced on the markets in June 2008, saw the world premier at the Geneva Motor Show, and will certainly contribute to the ongoing success of Škoda.

And finally a word on SEAT; SEAT delivered in the first three months 101,000 cars to customers although that means a minus of 7.5% worldwide. This is due to, first of all, two markets, home markets for SEAT in Europe, the home market Spain, and the very strong market of Italy for SEAT. But both markets were rather weak, a minus of 15% and 8% respectively.

And also SEAT is now in the situation of running out the current model Ibiza, which simply says that – on this chart you can see the new Ibiza. That will certainly fit very well to the brand's auto emission theme and we expect the Ibiza to become the icon of the SEAT range, and to start a new chapter in design and quality and volume for the SEAT brand.
So, Mr. Pötsch, please.

Well, let me take you through the financials now and let's start with the sales revenue which, as you know, excludes our joint venture activities in China which we report in summary within the equity results in the financial results.

The first three months of 2008, our sales excluding China increased by 2.2%. Sales revenue rose 1.4%, or 0.4 billion, compared to the first three months of 2007. Volume growth contributed 0.7 billion which was almost entirely offset by adverse currency effects, with regard principally to the U.S. dollar and British pound, not forgetting that our extensive hedging activities impact only at the operating results level rather than here at revenue.
Price was up a positive point 2 billion, also mix was a negative point 1 billion. Financial Services made an important point €2 billion additional contribution.

Let me now turn to operating profit. Price, mix and volume contributed a positive €0.3 billion. We had an impact of hedging of 0.2 billion from currencies. Despite the head wins of further increases in commodity prices, our continued efforts to improve the cost of our vehicles resulted in the saving of 0.2 billion in product costs. The €0.1 billion fixed costs/depreciation relates in part to an increase in start up costs for new products. Financial Services weathered the storm into financial markets and despite higher funding costs slightly improved last year's first quarter earnings.

Now let's turn to cash flow. In the Automotive Division cash flow operating activities was €2.2 billion. Cash flow from investing activities fell 300 million to €1.3 billion. However, please remember that in the first quarter last year we increased our investment in MIM. Excluding this impact as you can see in the footnote to the chart, investments rose by 356 million as we invested in products and on our new production facilities.

The operating cash flow reduced year-on-year. This is mainly due to a lower improvement in working capital when compared to the first quarter 2007. Here one must recall that in former years considerable efforts were made to achieve a sustainable improvement in working capital. Such an improvement cannot be repeated each year. Furthermore, higher volumes typically lead to higher inventories as we ensure the dealer network has sufficient supply.

Our CapEx ratio in the first quarter of 2008 was 3.9%, up from 3.2% for the comparable period 2007, reflecting our investments in new models. We expect to see CapEx pick up as the year progresses. The cash flow from operating activities coupled with our investment discipline contributed to a further improvement in net liquidity. At €14.2 billion Automotive net liquidity is 0.7 billion above our year-end 2007 cash position of 13.5 billion.

Let's take a look now at the financial performance of the different brands starting with the Volkswagen Passenger Car brand. Positive sales development together with further improvement in our cost efficiency combined to improve the operating results of the first quarter 2007 to a rounded €0.5 billion. Our wide geographic base from a core in Western Europe, encompassing Eastern Europe, China and Brazil allow the brand to weather the market uncertainty and provide a sure base for further growth in new emerging markets.

Audi's revenue declined slightly due to exchange range impacts. However, Audi's focus on cost discipline and the development of a broad product portfolio allowed Audi to yet again increase earnings into first quarter. Škoda's excellent volume performance translated into an improvement in operating result to 182 million. I have no doubt that the new Superb will provide a further boost going forward.

SEAT reported an operating profit of €12 million reflecting the tremendous work undertaken to improve the core business. The new Ibiza launching in the second quarter will be a very important milestone in securing the brand on a sustainable earnings base. Bentley reported stable earnings and Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles improved its earnings more than 50% reflecting the improved volume already mentioned.

Despite difficult financial market our Financial Services business managed an improvement in earnings. At this point I would like to mention the excellent progress in our Chinese business, which we have reported in the footnote as it is included using the equity method within the financial result. The recorded a proportional operating profit of 73 million euros more than double the performance in the first quarter 2007.

Now looking at the regional development, you can see a slightly mixed picture; vehicle sales in Europe and the remaining markets shows a mild decline which contrast to the slight increase in deliveries to customers Mr. Wittig described earlier. This is a seasonality issue, which will adjust itself in the second quarter and relate to the fall of Easter in late of the first quarter. All other regions recorded sales improvements. The sales revenue trends broadly mirror our vehicle sales.

The worsening picture on North America highlights again the challenge of exporting from Europe to the U.S. and as you already know I hope to be able to report more on how we will face this challenge in the next few months, once some key strategic decisions have been taken.

To sum up, first quarter 2008 was a positive quarter for the Volkswagen Group. Operating profit increased substantially by over 20% as did profit before tax and after-tax. Automotive liquidity is up and in these difficult times for finance, we grew our Financial Services earnings.
We've launched new and exciting products to maintain our momentum and are continuing to build the foundations for future growth in both our core markets and the emerging world markets.

And finally ladies and gentlemen let me turn to our 2008 outlook statement which you can read in full in the Interim Report. We expect demand for our Group vehicles to increase substantially especially in the Asia-Pacific, Central and Eastern Europe and South America regions. We continued to improve our processes and are systematically pursuing our disciplined approach to cost management. Together with the higher sales revenue resulting from the expected increase in unit sales this will help lift our operating profit for 2008 above the previous year's figure.

In addition, we continue to expect a positive net cash flow and a further improvement in the Automotive Division's liquidity position. Let me assure you our confidence in achieving these targets remains high. As my last comment for now please note that these forecasts do not take into account the effects of the acquisition of further shares of Scania on volume, earnings and financing data. We expect the transaction when it closes as we hope in mid-2008 to be accretive to both deliveries and earnings.
We have our first question from Jochen Gehrke with Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I have two questions if I may. First of all with regards to your cash flow you are still quite sizably below your medium-term target of 6% CapEx to sales. I wonder Mr. Pötsch whether you could state whether we will reach or see this number within the year 2008 or whether we will still be noticeably below that? And secondly with regards to your segmental reporting, once again we've seen a segment report where your intracompany eliminations have set a very level with €276 million. I wonder whether you could make clear when finally this number is going to come down, I mean in my spreadsheet at least this is now a triple-digit number for quite some quarters. Is it actually, it's almost 20% of Group EBIT now. How should we see the performance of each and every individual brand? Where should we allocate those? Do you really think you're giving us a clear picture here on divisional performance with such a high number? Thank you.

Okay, thank you very much. Jochen has two questions, the first question refers to our CapEx ratio and if we can give an outlook for 2008 and the second question is referring to our segment reporting and if we can give some more information about the line other. Thank you.

First of all with regards to the CapEx development we've seen an increase in the first quarter against the first quarter 2007 and following the usual seasonality pattern we can expect that we will see that this number going up further. As we already said we stick to limiting the framework for CapEx development at around 6% and I think from today's point of view there is a high likelihood that we will remain in this framework.

The second question is a question on the segment reporting on other items is to be answered like the following first of all clearly we want to show the performance of the single brands and as I was explaining in the earlier conference calls there is business going forward between the brands on the one hand and of course we have also to reflect intracompany profits by building up stock or moving down the stocks. So this figure is going to fluctuate going forward. It's very difficult to predict whether the figure will go up or down but it has nothing to do with in any extent situating any fog around the real performance figures of the single brands.

Sorry, may I just follow-up on that? On the segment reporting is it 276 million for quarter is this an indication to cash flow, is this also a cash near intracompany elimination because otherwise your brand cash performance is not nearly as high as your group-cash performance?
No you can allocate the 276 in a sense and clearly there is also a cash element included in that, but this doesn't change to any extent the key performance indicators of the group.
Okay, thank you.
We now move to Christian Breitsprecher with Sal. Oppenheimer please go ahead.

Yeah, good afternoon. Maybe firstly following up on the CapEx question, you said that CapEx would remain in the framework of 6%, we have been follower in the first quarter, so what is the CapEx ratio that we should expect for the full year, is it 5%, is it 5.5 or 6, maybe you can clarify that a little bit, and then secondly on Financial Services, could you tell us whether you're also using industrial net cash that you have at the moment to refinance Financial Services business and could you tell us to which extent you're doing that and where we could find these numbers in your interim report. And secondly on Financial Services, we had one of your competitors at BMW a big impact from the write-down of residual values. Can you elaborate a little bit on which risks you're facing in terms of residual value and your exposure to the U.S. market in that respect?

Yes, thank you Christian. So, we have three questions. The first question is about the CapEx again so if we can give CapEx ratio for this year, what we expect? The second question refers to the financial business financial services if we are using industrial cash to finance the financial services business and the last question is if we can give some information about the development of the residual values especially in the U.S? Thank you.

Though, first of all the question again related to CapEx development – clearly as I've stated we are looking at a situation where we believe will stay below 6%. It's very difficult to talk about any digit behind the comma and at this point I would like to remind you that of course ratio always depends on two sectors if the other sector is sales revenue and I think It should be very clear that also this number is not so easy to predict because it's heavily affected by exchange-rate effect as we saw already in the first quarter. But the best guess at this point in time is between 5 and 6 and I think fundamentally of a higher importance is that we are continuing our high discipline with regards to investment spent.

Turnaround to your questions regarding financial services, firstly you were asking on whether we use industrial-net cash to refinance the financial-service business. Principally speaking, we look at the situation of our two business units in a way that we see it has two separate financial schemes which are to be financed within themselves which doesn't say that we are not making an exception here or there. So for example when for example last year, during the summer period, we saw incredibly high spreads coming up it was very senseful to support financial service with industrial cash debt, that was brought back then in the month until yearend. The amount is always a very low single-digit number. So essentially it can be said we are dealing with two separate financing streams.

As far as the residual values are concerned, it's clear that the situation in general terms reflects the market situation and in so far it's first of all not surprising that the situation is somewhat more difficult in the U.S. than anywhere else in the world, fortunately we can say that probably related to the fact that we are more a niche player than any volume player, first of all, secondly, as you are well aware, we've always kept incentive spent levels to a level much lower than the average in the market. And thirdly, we have triggered a program already at the end of 2006 to stabilize residuals and we do see that these measures, which were partially precautionary measures are paying back now. So, this means, we proportionally can say that we are reasonably protected by our provisions in terms of residual values in America and we are significantly on the safe side if we look at the world picture.
So the next question please?
Our next question will come from John Lawson with Citigroup. Please go ahead.

Thanks very much. Good afternoon. You sounded quite pleased I think Mr. Pötsch on the Chinese joint ventures developments with quite a big increase in sales. I wonder whether you are really quite as satisfied with the profit performance, it just occurs to me that 73 million in that first quarter. Although, it was a lot higher than you achieved a year ago, after some pretty strong rises during 2007, is still – implicitly is still a pretty low margin perhaps only 2 to 3%. I just wondered what your thoughts were on that, whether there was a long way to go still on China, whether there was a really big seasonality in the quarter or what other explanation there might be? And then second question. I guess that we all have an appetite for bit more data on Financial Services at this time. I wonder whether you would be prepared to share with us one item that you dropped simply the penetration rate in the first quarter and whether you might say what the global cost of risk for the Financial Services was in that quarter. And may I just follow up on Christian's point about financing. I mean, it seems to me that the spreads you are looking at today are way higher, aren't they, than you were looking at even in August of last year? So, doesn't that actually make sense to put some of your industrial net cash into your Financial Services financing at this point? Thanks.

Okay, thank you, John. So, we have three questions. The first question is about our Chinese joint ventures. If you are satisfied with the profitability and what do we expect in the near future? The second question is about Financial Services. If you can give some further details about the penetration rate especially in the first quarter and the third question is about our high amount of liquidity if we should support the FS? Thank you.

So let me get started with the comment on our Chinese joint ventures and there I really got to remind you two situation, we had been in two or three years ago, where we really had to take a few decisions on a very massive restructuring program. And at that time, we launched this Olympic program, which in the meantime I think has reached a wide acceptance for the reason that it really delivered the results that we are expecting.

Now, there's one point besides to comment I would generally make here, if we look at just the three month performance which we is seasonality but what we should not forget is that we're able to turn around the situation in China in a very dramatic way without a few very key products being available and that's something which is about to change somewhere around the middle of this year and this is to say it and we were able to show the cars already at last motor show in China. It's going to be two cars will hit the real volume markets.

In China, we will officially present the cars to the wider public then at the occasion of the Olympic Games in China and shortly after we'll be able to deliver and that will be a step change in our Olympic program because at that time, then we will be in addition to the measures we have taken so far which was heavily concentrating on cost-cutting, performance improvements and the like quality improvement, we will from now on will be in a position to also to drive the further improvement process by introducing new cars into the market. This is going to change the situation very much to the more positive.

So to sum up shortly, we are not surprised but we view the situation clearly on the positive what we've reached so far and we're looking forward to a situation where we can play the game much more actively by introducing new cars to market.

As far as Financial Services are concerned, I unfortunately cannot talk about anything extraordinary in terms of the penetration rate specifically as far as the first quarter is concerned. I think we're continuing on the reasonably high level, we reached in several markets, there is nothing, which did significantly change in this first quarter.
No change in cost of risks?

Clearly, the cost of risk are to be seen but in saying this, I got to say here that if we look for example at delinquency rate then we see a development which is only different in the third or fourth digits. So it's not even clear whether this is characterizing a trend or whether it's not basically an unchanged situation. There is another area where it's a bit more significant, that's the wholesale situation, that's where dealer financing is concerned, there we saw a slight upturn in delinquency rates. We are fine on the leasing side. So over and above, we still have quite a playing ground between the risks, which really materialize and ones that we keep in our books to be prepared for a different situation. Very clearly, the spreads went up quite significantly and even if they turned little bit back in the meantime, it's absolutely clear that this is fundamental for the business.

Now having said this, I got to say that we very successfully were able to realize a few issues in billion dimension type for spreads which were benchmarked in the market. And so far, I think looking a little further down the road, yes we are still in a situation where spreads are higher than the longer-term average but part of what we currently see is also the way back to normalize the situation where, as hopefully we all know, a situation where we've seen the spreads, which were really negligible and not really reflecting the cost of finance. So in that sense, I think we will continue our very conservative policy in terms of financial services and what's currently taking place in a few markets. It's just a confirmation of the policy we've applied in earlier years, yes.
Thanks.
Okay, thank you. Can we have the next question please?
Certainly, our next question will come form Adam Jonas with Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Hi. Adam Jonas with Morgan Stanley. Good evening, every one. I just have three questions, and a follow up on John Lawson's question, just to be really very clear, are you telling us that you have not increased your provisioning for residual value risk which I presume you review probably constantly but at least on a quarterly basis, you have not raised the provision at all from the recent trend, is my first question. Because it would kind of be shocking if that were the case given just the reality of what's gong on in the market with your competitors.

The second question, regarding the intracompany loan, just specifically what is the amount of the loan as it stands right now? We know you do it, everyone does it, it's part of the business. Can you just quantify in at least rounded to the nearest billion, if you will, how much cash has been lent, how much of the industrial net cash has been lent to the financial sub, please.

And then finally last question, just on depreciation, I noticed that it declined in absolute terms pretty materially year-on-year in the first quarter. It seems to be at a level that was equal to when – a magnitude at least to when you reported your Q1 2003, yet the company is about 25 or 30% larger right now in revenue terms. So, why was the depreciation down so much when you are growing? Is this just a freaky thing for the quarter that we shouldn't pay attention to or, is this, there is some other explanation because it can affect your earnings quality too? Thanks.

Thank you, Adam. So we have three questions. The first question is again about the residual values and new question is do we have increased our provisions for our residual value risk this year. The second question is, you would like to have some further details about the amount of intracompany loans and the last question is about our depreciation, why did it decline in the first quarter and in comparison to the last year? Thank you.

So to the first question, it requires clear answer I believe. I did not at all say we didn't raise the provisions. I was saying that the provisions clearly cover any risk, which we can view right at this moment. Secondly on the intercompany loan I just can repeat what I already said it's a low single digit number. It doesn't make sense to make mention a number because it's fluctuating from month-to-month. It might be two; it might be three or four. It's a low single digit number. As far as depreciation is concerned first of all, I mean if you look back into earlier years we have realized CapEx to sales ratios the last few years of below 5% and this clearly leads to a lower basis for applying depreciation. And so far, it's completely normal development which we only will see going upwards again when we start investing more than in past years.

Okay, so just a follow-up on that last point. It's just a normal case of years of more efficient and lower investment, it's just we're now seeing that time lag where the depreciation is reflecting with the lag of the downward slope for your CapEx over the last three or four, five years, is that I think that's how you are explaining it. And if that's correct and we should continue to have D&A kind of lagging or bottoming out perhaps before rising again in coming periods, is that, that's fair?
I think that's fair

Okay, so we won't, so then we'll keep assuming that D&A possibly can continue to have more quarters of year-on-year reduction, which we won't want to extrapolate too much but this could continue at least for the next some quarters, is that fair?
Well, again we...
Or we won't?
We are leave – about to leave a period where we were clearly depreciating more than we spent.
Understood.

And now, we are about to change that and I think it's necessary to change it because clearly we cannot continue growing the company and still just spend 3% of sales revenue. That's not possible. And that's why I really say we will see an upturn in CapEx this year, which we consequently lead to higher depreciation rates.
That's very clear. Thank you.
Thank you. And let's have the next question please?
The next question comes from Thierry Huon with Exane Paribas. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon, its Thierry Huon speaking from Exane BNP Paribas. Just a really simple one. Could you give us some colors about you hedging situations for what the U.S. dollar of course but also the British pound and the Argentinean peso? Hello?
Okay, thank you Thierry so your question is about the impact of currencies so what is the situation referring to dollar, pound sterling and peso?
That's the hedging position?
Our hedging and the rate of our hedging activities. Okay, thank you Thierry.
